Forum Quorum
Despite the presence of numerous University officials, including President Eisenhower, the StudentAdministration Forum held last week failed to arrive
at any coherent, explanation, much less an evaluation,
of University undergraduate policies. While the forum
idea reflected a commendable desire on the part of the
sophomore class officers to establish a more direct line
of communication between undegraduates and the administration, the attempt was unsuccessful largely because of misplaced priorities and poor organization.
Controversial academic problems were relegated
to a bottom position on the agenda, while undue emphasis was placed on questions in the area of athletics,
absorbing an excessive amount of time. Consequently,
issues such as the desperate state of the advising system,
the poor quality of graduate instruction, the insufficient
number of courses, and the Bookstore were not discussed.
The poor attendance of undergraduates was only
partly the result of inadequate publicity. Many who were
aware of the Forum still stayed away, once again exhibiting their unfortunately characteristic response to
student affairs.
Those who would organize future forums might
bear in mind that an entire day is set aside when the
administration meets with the heads of student campus
activities. If such an arrangement is not feasible, then a
definite narrowing of the problems to be covered is
necessary.
The administration appears willing, even anxious
in one case, to subject themselves to undergraduate interrogation. Thorough organization and more student interest could yet result in a meaningful student-administration confrontation.

issues such as the desperate state of the advising system,

number of courses, and the Bookstore were not discussed.

partly the result of inadequate publicity. Many who were
aware of the Forum still stayed away, once again exhibiting their unfortunately characteristic response to

activities. If such an arrangement is not feasible, then a
definite narrowing of the problems to be covered is
necessary.

in one case, to subject themselves to undergraduate interrogation. Thorough organization and more student interest could yet result in a meaningful student-administration confrontation.
